threads.name: Anonymous
threads.com:
This board is dedicated to the discussion of history and the other humanities such as philosophy, religion, law, classical artwork, archeology, anthropology, ancient languages, etc. Please use /lit/ for discussions of literature. Threads should be about specific topics, and the creation of "general" threads is discouraged.

For the purpose of determining what is history, please do not start threads about events taking place less than 25 years ago. Historical discussions should be focused on past events, and not their contemporary consequences. Discussion of modern politics, current events, popular culture, or other non-historical topics should be posted elsewhere. General discussions about international culture should go on /int/.

/his/ is not /pol/, and Global Rule #3 is in effect. Do not try to treat this board as /pol/ with dates. Blatant racism and trolling will not be tolerated, and a high level of discourse is expected. History can be examined from many different conflicting viewpoints; please treat other posters with respect and address the content of their post instead of attacking their character.

When discussing history, please reference credible source material, and provide as much supporting information as possible in your posts.

threads.com: What do you think about the French idea of laicite, or extreme separation of church and state, where religion is largely kept out the public sphere and kept probably in the home and places of worship? This contrasts with the American idea of separation where preachers are banned from endorsing politicians but are still able to get involved in society and culture.

last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com:
>>14220222
It was an product of its time, of the very anti-religious Third Republic, which followed the very religious Second Empire. It ended up being largely useless, especially out in the provinces, where religious life and public life remained largely intertwined for many decades, but it did succeed in allowing non-religious thought to endure in major urban centres and literary works.
Nowadays, it's mostly a French cultural oddity, but it ended up becoming a surprisingly effective shield against the progression of Islam. with second- or third- generation Muslims becoming increasingly non-religious.

threads.com: Why is it that the Mesoamerican civilizations seemingly didn't evolve or develop from its very beginning to the Aztecs? Zapotecs lasted from 700BC to Columbus and they stayed the same. Meanwhile the Germanic tribes went from mudhuts in swamps to the Renaissance in less time

last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com:
no iron, not even bronze, no horses

Bronze in the old world seemed to be a result of good access to tin and copper. Iron smelting was perhaps partly a chance discovery and partly due to the developed state of metallurgy near the end of the bronze age and the necessity of looking for alternatives after the bronze age collapse. Horses took millenia to breed to the point they were decent draft animals, of course horses were hunted to extinction in the Americas. They would need to breed llamas, alpacas, deer or bison for this purpose, a task taking centuries of intensive selective breeding at the very least. In general there were certain important innovations they had no easy access too.

last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com:
>>14220003
Indeed. Not OP but look even further to Egyptian history or even Chinese dynasties of the past. Moving from copper to iron is a huge jump just like stone to paper.

last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com:
One thing people underestimate is the role of planned mass agriculture, particularly in areas where active water management is vital, in making a society stagnant.

Mesoamerica, Egypt, Iraq and China all suffered from the same set of circumstances. The development of a top-down bureaucracy to guide production and allocate resources left little room for free enterprise and organic social mobility (meaning the best and brightest were not selected for; just the most obedient and conformist). Over the course of centuries, what this selection process did was produce societies that did not innovate nearly as quickly as those that lacked planned mass agriculture. Because one, the population was ever more conformist and stuck in its ways, because that's how you reproduced successfully. And two, over time people became utterly dependent on existing systems.

The downside of this mutual dependence (obedience in exchange for functioning systems) is that whenever those systems failed, societies collapsed catastrophically - far more than any European society ever has, including after the fall of the Western Roman Empire. You need only look at Chinese civil wars and the total carnage that followed (typically after flooding, harvest failures and things like that, things that disrupted the system); they make not only World War I and World War II look civilized by comparison, but even the Thirty Years War, which killed a third of Germany's population.

Diaspora and tourism.

threads.sub: How bad was rural living during the early modern era?
threads.com:
I homestead myself, and after doing it for sometime I think rural living, especially pre-industrialization, is portrayed poorly. It has its issues for sure, but its far and away much better than urban living or living in a suburb. Most of the complaints I see about it are:
>Theres not much to do
Which is why you need to take up a hobby. Homebrewing, whittling, wood work, gardening, studying history/languages, reading, archery, HEMA. Theres no hand holding, you just do it.
>Its more work
Kind of. It has bouts of busy work that eat up your day and then days or even weeks of doing nothing but twiddling your thumbs aside from the most basic of chores. Its better than spending 10+ hours at the office/commuting and then sleeping.
